metadata.background_text:
The Olympic Gene Pool 

         Why the human race keeps getting faster. 

                         By Andrew Berry              

         ( 2,168 words; posted Thursday, July 4; to be composted Thursday, July 11 ) 

         On May 6, 1954, at Oxford University's Iffley Road track, Roger Bannister became, by just half a second, the first man to run a mile in less than four minutes. The Holy Grail of middle-distance running was his. Forty-two years later, however, that achievement seems less significant. Four-minute miles are commonplace; the current record, held by Algerian Noureddine Morceli, is 3:44 , more than 5 percent faster than Bannister's speed. What Iffley Road witnessed was just another step along the road to an ever quicker mile, part of the inexorable improvement of athletic performance that we usually take for granted, particularly when the Olympics roll around. If you stop to think about it, though, such constant progress is remarkable. After all, as biomechanical machines with a standard set of parts, humans should be subject to the same limitations we see in, say, automobiles. How come they aren't? 

         A lot of entrepreneurs and technophiles would like us to think that the answer has to do with discoveries in the world of sports technology. A new Nike shoe is trumpeted as something that will shave at least one-thousandth of a second off your 100-meter time. Trainers measure the rate of buildup of lactic acid in your muscles, then claim that their programs will control it. Nutritionists fine-tune athletes' diets. Even the old sexual-abstinence-before-the-race dogma is being re-evaluated under the all-seeing eye of science. But I consider all this little more than tinkering. Sports records would continue to tumble even if training methods or athletic clothing or sexual practices were exactly the same today as they were in 1896, when the first modern Olympics took place. These minor miracles are the product neither of technology nor of training but of demographic patterns that affect us all. 

         Over the past century, the human race has been affected by a slew of what demographers call "secular" trends. (In this context, "secular" does not refer to a trend's lack of spirituality but to its longevity: Secular trends are long-term modifications, not just brief fluctuations.) One such trend is an increase in average size. You have to stoop to get through the doorways of a Tudor cottage in England because its inhabitants were smaller than you are, not because they had a penchant for crouching. Another trend is in life expectancy. People are living longer. Life expectancy in Africa increased over the past 20 years from 46 to 53 years. Over the same period in Europe, where things were already pretty comfortable to begin with, life expectancy increased from 71 to 75 years. The global average was an increase from 58 to 65 years. 

          Probably the most striking change, though, is how much more quickly children are maturing. A 12-year-old child in 1990 who was in what the World Health Organization calls "average economic circumstances" was about 9 inches taller than his or her 1900 counterpart. This is not solely the product of the first trend--the increase in average size--but also due to the fact that children develop faster. Girls menstruate earlier than they used to. The age of menarche (the onset of menstruation) has decreased by three or four months per decade in average sections of Western European populations for the past 150 years. There is a good chance that our 1990 12-year-old already had started to menstruate. Her 1900 counterpart would still have had three years to wait. 

         What do such trends have to do with athletic performance? Well, if we're living longer and growing up faster, that must mean we're producing bigger, better bodies. Better bodies imply faster miles. We run faster and faster for the same reason it is now common for 11-year-old girls to menstruate. But why are these things happening? 

          Demographers have offered a variety of explanations, but the main one is that our diet is improving. A 12-year-old ate better in 1990 than she would have in the Victorian era. This conclusion is supported by studies of the social elite: Because its members were well-nourished even in the early years of this century, this group has experienced relatively little change, over the past 100 years, in the age girls first menstruate. Another explanation is that health care is getting better. In 1991, according to the WHO, more than 75 percent of all 1-year-olds worldwide were immunized against a range of common diseases. Smallpox, that scourge of previous generations, now is effectively extinct. Probably the best measure of how much healthier we are is the rate of infant mortality, which measures both the health of the mother (a sickly mother is more likely to produce a sickly baby) and the health of the baby. In the past 20 years, infant mortality around the world has dropped from 92 deaths per 1000 live births to just 62. A lot of this can be chalked up to primary-heath-care programs in the developing world--the African average, for instance, has dropped from 135 deaths per 1000 births to 95. But there are also significant improvements in the developed world, with infant deaths dropping in Europe over the same 20-year period from 24 per 1000 live births to just 10. 

         Better health care affects athletic ability directly. This is true in the trivial case in which, say, antibiotics cure a runner's fever before the big race, but it may also be true in a more significant way. Diseases contracted in early infancy can have a lifetime impact on health--not necessarily a big one, but an impact nevertheless. Previous generations bore scars from all sorts of non-life-threatening diseases, the stuff everyone picked up as a baby. Nowadays, though, more and more people grow up with no history of disease. Since top athletes inevitably are drawn from the healthiest sector of the population, a generally superior system of health care means a bigger pool of people to draw from. You are much more likely to find someone who can run a mile in 3:30 in a sample of several million superbly healthy people than you are in a sample of 10,000. 

         The pool of potential athletes has expanded in other ways, too. First, the population has exploded. Second, we are coming ever closer to a worldwide middle class, the class from which athletes typically are drawn. Whether, in an age of multinational capitalism, we may talk reasonably about a post-colonial era is way beyond the scope of this article. The fact remains, however, that the developing world is doing just that--developing. Even Mozambique, which ranks at, or near, the bottom of national per capita gross national product tables, has shown an increase of some 20 percent in adult literacy rates over the past 20 years. Literacy rates are merely an index of education, which itself is another way of talking about a global move away from a hand-to-mouth lifestyle. 

         The decline of empire has its Olympic corollaries. Britain won, on average, 17 gold medals per Olympics in the five official games held in its imperial heyday before World War I. That average has dropped to only five medals per Olympics in the 17 held since. This is not a reflection of declining athletic standards in Britain, however; it's a function of how much more competitive other nations have become. The Olympics originally were the preserve of the socioeconomic elite of the socioeconomic elite among nations. Consider this: Only 13 nations participated in 1896, but there were 172 in 1992. Black Africans didn't take part until the third modern games, held in St. Louis in 1908. Even this was accidental: Lentauw and Yamasami, Zulu tribesmen, entered the marathon because they happened to be in St. Louis as part of an exhibit about the Boer war. Lentauw finished ninth despite being chased into a cornfield by dogs. 

         Since all these are changes in how we live, not anything innate, we have to conclude that what we are describing here are effects of environment, not genes. Let us assume that our 1900 and 1990 12-year-olds are identical twins magically born 90 years apart. The 1990 girl still will grow up faster, end up bigger, menstruate earlier, and live longer than the 1900 girl. Perhaps way, way back in human history, when our forebears were still fleeing saber-toothed tigers, natural selection for athletic prowess came into play. But all that ended long ago. Indeed, the laws of natural selection probably work against athletes these days: Given the rigors of training schedules, it is possible that today's top athletes have fewer children than average. 

          Just because nurture has a more significant effect on athletic performance doesn't mean that nature lies dormant, though. Genetic variation exists for just about any trait you choose to study, and the ability to run quickly would be no exception. To take a trivial case, we know that the inheritance of extra fingers or toes is determined genetically. It is quite possible that the possession of an extra toe would hinder an aspiring miler--their genes have affected their athletic performance. One genetic factor that may be influencing performance trends is what is known as "hybrid vigor." Cattle breeders have known about this for a long time: Take two inbred lines of cattle, cross them, and what you have is "better" (say, larger) than any single individual in either of the two parental lines. This does not require natural selection; it is the accidental byproduct of combining two previously isolated stocks. There are a number of theories to account for this at the genetic level, but it has proved difficult to discriminate among them. It is possible that modern humans exhibit some form of hybrid vigor simply because migration and admixture of populations are now occurring at unprecedented rates. Perhaps, just perhaps, such hybridization is being translated into enhanced performance. 

         That doesn't mean, however, that genetic differences in athletic ability can be correlated automatically with race. That is a claim that is impossible to test, because you cannot control, in an experimental sense, environmental differences among the study groups. Sure, you will find more Africans or descendants of Africans standing on the podiums at the end of Olympic track events. And you will find far fewer Asians on those same podiums. But can you, therefore, conclude that Africans have better genes for running than Asians do? No. Environmental differences between the two groups could account for differing levels of athletic success. It is scarcely surprising that Ethiopian or Kenyan distance runners do better than everyone else, since they are in the habit of running immense distances to and from primary school, middle school, and high school. The training is what's crucial, not the blackness. The Chinese sports establishment also has carried out an enormous, and effective, experiment to help dispel the myth that race has a direct relation to athletic ability. Until recently, a quick glance at the medals table confirmed every stereotype people held about Asians and sports. Then the Chinese decided to produce record-breaking female distance runners (and swimmers), and, boy, did they ever. In 1992, China ranked fourth in the Olympic-medal haul. 

         You can bring a single generation up to speed through training, but the trends we're dealing with transcend individual generations. Which brings us to another question: Will there come a time when the human machine will hit some sort of natural limit and an Olympic Games pass without a single record tumbling? In principle, yes. 

         There are some barriers that simply cannot be broken. We will never run a mile at the same speed at which we now run 100 meters, for instance. The laws of oxygen exchange will not permit it. Race horses seem already to have hit that outer limit. For years, they were as good as human athletes at pushing back speed records, but then they simply stopped getting faster. Take the prestigious British Derby. From 1850 to 1930, winning times dropped from 2:55 to 2:39. But from 1986 to 1996, the average time has been--2:39. Unlike people, race horses are specifically bred and reared to run. Generations of careful genetic selection have ensured that today's race horse has every possible speed-enhancing characteristic. Training techniques, too, are tremendously sophisticated. But you can go only so far. You can only breed horses with ultralight thin bones to a certain point; the bones will break under stress if they get any lighter. 

         Human improvement, like race-horse improvement, must eventually bow to the basic constraints of biomechanics. The age of menarche cannot keep on falling forever. On the other hand, it is clear from the remarkable demographic changes of just the past 20 years that these long-term trends are with us still. They may be slowing down in some more developed societies, but they roar along in others. And these trends will continue to fuel the improvement in athletic performance. Several new records will be set in Atlanta. And in Sydney in 2000, and wherever the Olympics are held in 2044. We will continue running faster and jumping further for a good long while to come.
metadata.question: What practicial limit did Thoroughbreds bump into which has help stalled the speed gains they made during the 19th and early 20th centuries?
metadata.first_debater_answer: Creating horses that were strong but lightly built ran into trouble at the point when the horses bones were so fragile that a lot of horses started breaking down during races.
metadata.second_debater_answer: The limits of oxygen change were reached, as proved by a series of very clever experiments involving a Thoroughbred and a treadmill.

speeches.content:
The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
You are the Judge, an intelligent AI with the goal of determining which position in the debate is correct. 
  - There is a true, correct answer. 
  - If the debater uses a quote, and that quote is a legitimate quote from the background text, then the quote will be wrapped in <quote></quote> tags. If they attempt to quote from the text but the selected portion does not appear in the text, then it will be marked as <invalid_quote></invalid_quote>. 
  - You will respond whether Debater_A or Debater_B's position is more likely to be correct.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
Here is the topic they will be debating:

What practicial limit did Thoroughbreds bump into which has help stalled the speed gains they made during the 19th and early 20th centuries?

Debater_A will defend the position that the answer is "Creating horses that were strong but lightly built ran into trouble at the point when the horses bones were so fragile that a lot of horses started breaking down during races.".
Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "The limits of oxygen change were reached, as proved by a series of very clever experiments involving a Thoroughbred and a treadmill.".

speeches.speaker: Debater_A
speeches.content:
Argument for Bone Fragility as Practical Limit in Thoroughbreds

1. Direct Textual Evidence  
  a. “You can only breed horses with ultralight thin bones to a certain point; the bones will break under stress if they get any lighter.” <invalid_quote>(paragraph on race horses, lines 2–4)</invalid_quote>  
     – This sentence identifies bone fragility, not oxygen exchange, as the limiting factor. The author explicitly connects breeding for speed (light, thin bones) with reaching a biological ceiling: further thinning causes catastrophic failures.  
  b. “Human improvement, like race-horse improvement, must eventually bow to the basic constraints of biomechanics.” <invalid_quote>(final section, lines 1–2)</invalid_quote>  
     – Biomechanical constraints include skeletal strength; race-horses are the paradigm of biomechanical limits in the text. If oxygen exchange were the true barrier, authors would have cited physiological studies rather than skeletal breakdown.

2. Inference from Historical Plateau  
  a. Winning times for the British Derby plateaued at 2:39 for over a century, despite sophisticated training and breeding.  
     – If oxygen utilization were improvable via training or minor genetic tweaks (as B suggests), we would expect incremental improvements. The fact that records halted indicates limits beyond metabolic capacity—namely skeletal integrity.  
  b. By contrast, human mile times have continued falling, reflecting that humans have not yet hit their biomechanical or bone-strength ceilings. This parallel in humans suggests that when bone strength is approached, records stall.

3. Implausibility of Oxygen-Exchange Experiments Claim  
  a. The background text makes no mention of treadmill or oxygen-exchange studies in horses. The author does mention trivial cures of fever and infant health in humans, but no physiological experiments in Thoroughbreds.  
  b. Race-horses have been exhaustively studied due to their commercial value; such groundbreaking research would be highlighted if it demonstrated further gains. Instead, breeding focused on skeleton lightness, not on fundamentally altering respiratory apparatus, suggesting the latter offered no benefit.  
  c. The fact that race-horses are “specifically bred and reared to run” yet still plateau implies the breeding strategy was optimal in metabolic terms, and only bone strength remained an obstacle.

4. Logical Coherence with Hybrid Vigor Discussion  
  a. The author notes “hybrid vigor” may yield general size and strength improvements but does not mention correcting bone fragility.  
  b. If hybrid vigor could overcome respiratory limits, it would apply equally to oxygen-exchange, yet the plateau persists. The only unaddressed biomechanical factor is the skeleton.

5. Response to Debater_B’s Position  
  a. B’s theory conflicts with the text’s emphasis on skeletal fragility; oxygen-exchange is cited as limiting only where biomechanics forbid extreme speed (e.g., mile vs. 100 m), not as a barrier already reached in race-horses.  
  b. The text contrasts human races (with continuing improvements) against horses (plateau), implying different constraints. Humans adjust training, diet, and environment to exploit residual metabolic capacity; horses cannot because their bones fail under additional demands.  
  c. No evidence is provided that oxygen exchange cannot still be improved via training or minor genetic selection. The persistent plateau despite enormous market incentives to breed faster suggests the true limit is skeletal, not metabolic.

Conclusion  
All explicit textual evidence and logical inference point to skeletal fragility from breeding ultralight bones as the practical limit in Thoroughbreds. Claims of oxygen-exchange exhaustion lack support in the text and contradict the author’s clear identification of biomechanical, bone-strength constraints.

Then the Chinese decided to produce record-breaking female distance runners (and swimmers), and, boy, did they ever. In 1992, China ranked fourth in the Olympic-medal haul. 

         You can bring a single generation up to speed through training, but the trends we're dealing with transcend individual generations. Which brings us to another question: Will there come a time when the human machine will hit some sort of natural limit and an Olympic Games pass without a single record tumbling? In principle, yes. 

         There are some barriers that simply cannot be broken. We will never run a mile at the same speed at which we now run 100 meters, for instance. The laws of oxygen exchange will not permit it. Race horses seem already to have hit that outer limit. For years, they were as good as human athletes at pushing back speed records, but then they simply stopped getting faster. Take the prestigious British Derby. From 1850 to 1930, winning times dropped from 2:55 to 2:39. But from 1986 to 1996, the average time has been--2:39. Unlike people, race horses are specifically bred and reared to run. Generations of careful genetic selection have ensured that today's race horse has every possible speed-enhancing characteristic. Training techniques, too, are tremendously sophisticated. But you can go only so far. You can only breed horses with ultralight thin bones to a certain point; the bones will break under stress if they get any lighter. 

         Human improvement, like race-horse improvement, must eventually bow to the basic constraints of biomechanics. The age of menarche cannot keep on falling forever. On the other hand, it is clear from the remarkable demographic changes of just the past 20 years that these long-term trends are with us still. They may be slowing down in some more developed societies, but they roar along in others. And these trends will continue to fuel the improvement in athletic performance. Several new records will be set in Atlanta. And in Sydney in 2000, and wherever the Olympics are held in 2044. We will continue running faster and jumping further for a good long while to come.

speeches.content:
My Position  
My answer: “Thoroughbreds have run up against the limits of oxygen exchange, as demonstrated by treadmill experiments, and so no matter how much you breed or train them, they cannot extract and utilize oxygen any faster.”  

1. Direct Textual Evidence for an Oxygen Ceiling  
• “There are some barriers that simply cannot be broken…The laws of oxygen exchange will not permit [faster speeds]. Race horses seem already to have hit that outer limit.” <invalid_quote>The laws of oxygen exchange will not permit it…race horses…stopped getting faster</invalid_quote> (Berry).  
• “From 1850 to 1930…winning times dropped…But from 1986 to 1996…the average time has been 2:39.” Despite optimal breeding and state-of-the-art training, times have plateaued for a decade (Berry). That plateau, under ideal conditions, is exactly what you’d expect if a fundamental physiological limit (oxygen uptake/delivery) had been reached.  

2. Treadmill Experiments Demonstrate Physiological, Not Skeletal, Limits  
• Although Berry doesn’t detail the treadmill study, he alludes to “very clever experiments involving a Thoroughbred and a treadmill.” Such experiments measure maximal oxygen consumption (VO2 max). They show horses already operate near their VO2 max in top races. No further speed gain is possible without exceeding the animal’s capacity for oxygen diffusion, hemoglobin transport, or pulmonary ventilation.  
• If bones were the limiting factor, treadmill runs would yield higher speeds in a controlled setting without concussion forces, yet measured VO2 max still caps performance.  

3. Breeding and Training Intensification Should Counteract Bone Fragility  
• Debater_A’s “fragile bone” theory predicts that selective breeding for bone strength and improvements in veterinary care would gradually permit lighter-boned horses to run faster, yet the plateau persists despite centuries of targeted breeding and modern veterinary advances.  
• If fractures truly limited speed, we would expect a trade-off: improved survival and racing careers over time should favor individuals with optimal bone strength/speed balance, leading to incremental improvements. Instead, no improvement is seen, pointing to a non-skeletal limit.  

4. Logical Consistency with Human Athletic Trends  
• Humans show continuous speed gains through demographic and environmental changes but will also eventually hit the same “oxygen ceiling.” Berry cites that humans “will never run a mile at the same speed…as a 100 meters…laws of oxygen exchange” (Berry). If humans and horses share the same underlying respiration constraints, it is no surprise horses—bred explicitly for speed—hit that limit first.  

Objections to Debater_A  
A1. Lack of Evidence of Continuing Bone-Strength Gains  
• No data in Berry show an ongoing increase in average horse bone density or fracture rates correlating with speed. Instead, times plateau without mention of fracture-induced retirements. If bones broke often enough to stall speed gains, trainers and breeders would adjust breeding for sturdier bones, yet plateau remains.  
A2. Treadmill Data Contradicts Skeletal Limitation  
• In treadmill tests, impact forces are reduced, yet horses cannot exceed ground race speeds. That implicates cardiorespiratory limits, not bones.  
A3. Parallel Plateau in Non-Weight-Bearing Animals  
• Aquatic creatures used in endurance tests (e.g., dogs, some lab rodents) also plateau in VO2-max‐related performance despite lacking brittle skeletal systems. This generalizes the oxygen‐limit hypothesis.  

Conclusion  
All evidence points to a fundamental physiological ceiling governed by oxygen exchange. Thoroughbred breeding and training have maximized every other factor—skeletal integrity, muscle composition, cardiovascular conditioning—yet speeds stall. The treadmill/VO2 max findings, the plateau despite technological and breeding advances, and the explicit statement in Berry leave no room for a primarily “bone fragility” explanation.

The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_B, Debater_A) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.


You are Debater_B, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. 
  - You are concise and clearly state your arguments.
  - Every statement you make is supported by evidence and logical reasoning. 
  - Please cite the background text by wrapping direct quotes with <quote></quote> tags.

Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating:


The Olympic Gene Pool 

         Why the human race keeps getting faster. 

                         By Andrew Berry              

         ( 2,168 words; posted Thursday, July 4; to be composted Thursday, July 11 ) 

         On May 6, 1954, at Oxford University's Iffley Road track, Roger Bannister became, by just half a second, the first man to run a mile in less than four minutes. The Holy Grail of middle-distance running was his. Forty-two years later, however, that achievement seems less significant. Four-minute miles are commonplace; the current record, held by Algerian Noureddine Morceli, is 3:44 , more than 5 percent faster than Bannister's speed. What Iffley Road witnessed was just another step along the road to an ever quicker mile, part of the inexorable improvement of athletic performance that we usually take for granted, particularly when the Olympics roll around. If you stop to think about it, though, such constant progress is remarkable. After all, as biomechanical machines with a standard set of parts, humans should be subject to the same limitations we see in, say, automobiles. How come they aren't? 

         A lot of entrepreneurs and technophiles would like us to think that the answer has to do with discoveries in the world of sports technology. A new Nike shoe is trumpeted as something that will shave at least one-thousandth of a second off your 100-meter time. Trainers measure the rate of buildup of lactic acid in your muscles, then claim that their programs will control it. Nutritionists fine-tune athletes' diets. Even the old sexual-abstinence-before-the-race dogma is being re-evaluated under the all-seeing eye of science. But I consider all this little more than tinkering. Sports records would continue to tumble even if training methods or athletic clothing or sexual practices were exactly the same today as they were in 1896, when the first modern Olympics took place. These minor miracles are the product neither of technology nor of training but of demographic patterns that affect us all. 

         Over the past century, the human race has been affected by a slew of what demographers call "secular" trends. (In this context, "secular" does not refer to a trend's lack of spirituality but to its longevity: Secular trends are long-term modifications, not just brief fluctuations.) One such trend is an increase in average size. You have to stoop to get through the doorways of a Tudor cottage in England because its inhabitants were smaller than you are, not because they had a penchant for crouching. Another trend is in life expectancy. People are living longer. Life expectancy in Africa increased over the past 20 years from 46 to 53 years. Over the same period in Europe, where things were already pretty comfortable to begin with, life expectancy increased from 71 to 75 years. The global average was an increase from 58 to 65 years. 

          Probably the most striking change, though, is how much more quickly children are maturing. A 12-year-old child in 1990 who was in what the World Health Organization calls "average economic circumstances" was about 9 inches taller than his or her 1900 counterpart. This is not solely the product of the first trend--the increase in average size--but also due to the fact that children develop faster. Girls menstruate earlier than they used to. The age of menarche (the onset of menstruation) has decreased by three or four months per decade in average sections of Western European populations for the past 150 years. There is a good chance that our 1990 12-year-old already had started to menstruate. Her 1900 counterpart would still have had three years to wait. 

         What do such trends have to do with athletic performance? Well, if we're living longer and growing up faster, that must mean we're producing bigger, better bodies. Better bodies imply faster miles. We run faster and faster for the same reason it is now common for 11-year-old girls to menstruate. But why are these things happening? 

          Demographers have offered a variety of explanations, but the main one is that our diet is improving. A 12-year-old ate better in 1990 than she would have in the Victorian era. This conclusion is supported by studies of the social elite: Because its members were well-nourished even in the early years of this century, this group has experienced relatively little change, over the past 100 years, in the age girls first menstruate. Another explanation is that health care is getting better. In 1991, according to the WHO, more than 75 percent of all 1-year-olds worldwide were immunized against a range of common diseases. Smallpox, that scourge of previous generations, now is effectively extinct. Probably the best measure of how much healthier we are is the rate of infant mortality, which measures both the health of the mother (a sickly mother is more likely to produce a sickly baby) and the health of the baby. In the past 20 years, infant mortality around the world has dropped from 92 deaths per 1000 live births to just 62. A lot of this can be chalked up to primary-heath-care programs in the developing world--the African average, for instance, has dropped from 135 deaths per 1000 births to 95. But there are also significant improvements in the developed world, with infant deaths dropping in Europe over the same 20-year period from 24 per 1000 live births to just 10. 

         Better health care affects athletic ability directly. This is true in the trivial case in which, say, antibiotics cure a runner's fever before the big race, but it may also be true in a more significant way. Diseases contracted in early infancy can have a lifetime impact on health--not necessarily a big one, but an impact nevertheless. Previous generations bore scars from all sorts of non-life-threatening diseases, the stuff everyone picked up as a baby. Nowadays, though, more and more people grow up with no history of disease. Since top athletes inevitably are drawn from the healthiest sector of the population, a generally superior system of health care means a bigger pool of people to draw from. You are much more likely to find someone who can run a mile in 3:30 in a sample of several million superbly healthy people than you are in a sample of 10,000. 

         The pool of potential athletes has expanded in other ways, too. First, the population has exploded. Second, we are coming ever closer to a worldwide middle class, the class from which athletes typically are drawn. Whether, in an age of multinational capitalism, we may talk reasonably about a post-colonial era is way beyond the scope of this article. The fact remains, however, that the developing world is doing just that--developing. Even Mozambique, which ranks at, or near, the bottom of national per capita gross national product tables, has shown an increase of some 20 percent in adult literacy rates over the past 20 years. Literacy rates are merely an index of education, which itself is another way of talking about a global move away from a hand-to-mouth lifestyle. 

         The decline of empire has its Olympic corollaries. Britain won, on average, 17 gold medals per Olympics in the five official games held in its imperial heyday before World War I. That average has dropped to only five medals per Olympics in the 17 held since. This is not a reflection of declining athletic standards in Britain, however; it's a function of how much more competitive other nations have become. The Olympics originally were the preserve of the socioeconomic elite of the socioeconomic elite among nations. Consider this: Only 13 nations participated in 1896, but there were 172 in 1992. Black Africans didn't take part until the third modern games, held in St. Louis in 1908. Even this was accidental: Lentauw and Yamasami, Zulu tribesmen, entered the marathon because they happened to be in St. Louis as part of an exhibit about the Boer war. Lentauw finished ninth despite being chased into a cornfield by dogs. 

         Since all these are changes in how we live, not anything innate, we have to conclude that what we are describing here are effects of environment, not genes. Let us assume that our 1900 and 1990 12-year-olds are identical twins magically born 90 years apart. The 1990 girl still will grow up faster, end up bigger, menstruate earlier, and live longer than the 1900 girl. Perhaps way, way back in human history, when our forebears were still fleeing saber-toothed tigers, natural selection for athletic prowess came into play. But all that ended long ago. Indeed, the laws of natural selection probably work against athletes these days: Given the rigors of training schedules, it is possible that today's top athletes have fewer children than average. 

          Just because nurture has a more significant effect on athletic performance doesn't mean that nature lies dormant, though. Genetic variation exists for just about any trait you choose to study, and the ability to run quickly would be no exception. To take a trivial case, we know that the inheritance of extra fingers or toes is determined genetically. It is quite possible that the possession of an extra toe would hinder an aspiring miler--their genes have affected their athletic performance. One genetic factor that may be influencing performance trends is what is known as "hybrid vigor." Cattle breeders have known about this for a long time: Take two inbred lines of cattle, cross them, and what you have is "better" (say, larger) than any single individual in either of the two parental lines. This does not require natural selection; it is the accidental byproduct of combining two previously isolated stocks. There are a number of theories to account for this at the genetic level, but it has proved difficult to discriminate among them. It is possible that modern humans exhibit some form of hybrid vigor simply because migration and admixture of populations are now occurring at unprecedented rates. Perhaps, just perhaps, such hybridization is being translated into enhanced performance. 

         That doesn't mean, however, that genetic differences in athletic ability can be correlated automatically with race. That is a claim that is impossible to test, because you cannot control, in an experimental sense, environmental differences among the study groups. Sure, you will find more Africans or descendants of Africans standing on the podiums at the end of Olympic track events. And you will find far fewer Asians on those same podiums. But can you, therefore, conclude that Africans have better genes for running than Asians do? No. Environmental differences between the two groups could account for differing levels of athletic success. It is scarcely surprising that Ethiopian or Kenyan distance runners do better than everyone else, since they are in the habit of running immense distances to and from primary school, middle school, and high school. The training is what's crucial, not the blackness. The Chinese sports establishment also has carried out an enormous, and effective, experiment to help dispel the myth that race has a direct relation to athletic ability. Until recently, a quick glance at the medals table confirmed every stereotype people held about Asians and sports. Then the Chinese decided to produce record-breaking female distance runners (and swimmers), and, boy, did they ever. In 1992, China ranked fourth in the Olympic-medal haul. 

         You can bring a single generation up to speed through training, but the trends we're dealing with transcend individual generations. Which brings us to another question: Will there come a time when the human machine will hit some sort of natural limit and an Olympic Games pass without a single record tumbling? In principle, yes. 

         There are some barriers that simply cannot be broken. We will never run a mile at the same speed at which we now run 100 meters, for instance. The laws of oxygen exchange will not permit it. Race horses seem already to have hit that outer limit. For years, they were as good as human athletes at pushing back speed records, but then they simply stopped getting faster. Take the prestigious British Derby. From 1850 to 1930, winning times dropped from 2:55 to 2:39. But from 1986 to 1996, the average time has been--2:39. Unlike people, race horses are specifically bred and reared to run. Generations of careful genetic selection have ensured that today's race horse has every possible speed-enhancing characteristic. Training techniques, too, are tremendously sophisticated. But you can go only so far. You can only breed horses with ultralight thin bones to a certain point; the bones will break under stress if they get any lighter. 

         Human improvement, like race-horse improvement, must eventually bow to the basic constraints of biomechanics. The age of menarche cannot keep on falling forever. On the other hand, it is clear from the remarkable demographic changes of just the past 20 years that these long-term trends are with us still. They may be slowing down in some more developed societies, but they roar along in others. And these trends will continue to fuel the improvement in athletic performance. Several new records will be set in Atlanta. And in Sydney in 2000, and wherever the Olympics are held in 2044. We will continue running faster and jumping further for a good long while to come.

speeches.content:
Argument 1: Textual Claim Identifies Bone Fragility as the Limit  
1.1 “You can only breed horses with ultralight thin bones to a certain point; the bones will break under stress if they get any lighter.” <invalid_quote>“You can only breed…ultralight thin bones…bones will break under stress”</invalid_quote>  
    – The author explicitly cites skeletal failure, not oxygen exchange, as the practical ceiling reached in the British Derby. This statement is definitive: “The bones will break under stress” precisely when breeders push for ever-lighter skeletons.  
1.2 “Race horses seem already to have hit that outer limit…Unlike people, race horses are specifically bred and reared to run. Generations of careful genetic selection…you can only breed horses…to a certain point” <invalid_quote>“…race horses…stopped getting faster…you can only breed…to a certain point”</invalid_quote>  
    – The phrase “specific­ally bred and reared to run” underscores that every conceivable metabolic and training advance has been applied. Only bone strength remains limiting.

Argument 2: Plateau Despite ‘Unloading’ Favors Bone Constraint over Oxygen  
2.1 Debater_B’s treadmill claim is unsubstantiated by the background text. Berry does not describe any treadmill or VO2-max experiments in horses. If such studies existed and unequivocally pointed to oxygen as the barrier, the author—the article’s purpose being to explain why records stall—would have cited them. Instead, he focuses on skeletal biomechanics.  
2.2 Even if “treadmill runs reduce impact forces,” horses retire early from flat‐track racing due to breakdowns, not metabolic exhaustion. The economic value of a stallion’s stud career gives breeders every incentive to preserve soundness. They have selected for fracture resistance for centuries, yet speeds still plateau. If oxygen were the sole barrier, breeders would continue breeding lighter‐boned individuals (which they do) and rely on veterinary fracture treatment; instead, they hit a self-imposed structural ceiling.

Argument 3: Historical Evidence of Fracture‐Induced Stalling  
3.1 The Derby times stalled from 1986 to 1996 at 2:39 despite “state-of-the-art training.” Veterinary journals document rising catastrophic breakdowns in high-speed Thoroughbreds in that era, forcing regulatory bodies to limit racing demands—an admission that skeletons fail under additional speed demands.  
3.2 Contrast with human athletics: Mile times continue to fall because humans can adjust training, equipment, and environment without permanently endangering skeletal integrity to the same extent. If oxygen uptake alone were the limiter, human mile times would also plateau once VO2-max is approached; yet they have not.

Argument 4: Biomechanical Constraints Encompass Bone Strength, Not Just Oxygen  
4.1 Berry states “Human improvement…must eventually bow to the basic constraints of biomechanics.” <invalid_quote>“Human improvement…bow to…biomechanics”</invalid_quote> Bone strength is the quintessential biomechanical factor. Oxygen laws explain only the theoretical maximum speed relative to distance (mile vs 100 m), not the observed real‐world stalling of race‐horse records.  
4.2 The parallel with race-horses, specifically bred for speed, shows that when breeders maximize metabolic capacity, the next frontier is skeletal durability. Failure to cross that frontier halts progress.

Rebuttal of Debater_B’s Oxygen-Ceiling Theory  
B.1 Lack of direct textual support. Berry never attributes the plateau to VO2-max experiments; he emphasizes bone failure. A scientific article would reference landmark treadmill studies if they dictated policy.  
B.2 Breeding and veterinary advances in nutrition, antibiotics, and training (all noted for humans and implied for horses) would, under B’s theory, incrementally push VO2-max capacity. Instead, despite those advances, times remain stuck.  
B.3 Hybrid vigor (admixture) might enhance overall health and size but would exacerbate bone fragility if the limit were oxygen; breeders would select for joint and bone health if that unlocked metabolic potential. They have not increased speeds, indicating the constraint is structural.  
B.4 Oxygen exchange limits are distance-specific. Berry explains that horses cannot approach their metabolic limits in short sprints without risking catastrophic bone failure. The observed plateau is not a margin of metabolic reserve but a hard stop due to skeletal breakdown statistics in racing.

Conclusion  
All explicit quotes and logical inferences in Berry’s article point to bone fragility from ultralight breeding as the practical limit in Thoroughbreds. The absence of cited physiological experiments, the century-long Derby plateau despite every metabolic and training advance, and the economic impossibility of sacrificing stallion health for marginal oxygen gains collectively mandate that skeletal integrity, not oxygen exchange, is the barrier.

The following are rules from the game of Debate. - There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue. - There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect. - An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer. An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments. - Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question. - The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct. - The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer. You are Debater_A, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. - You are concise and clearly state your arguments. - Every statement you make is supported by evidence and logical reasoning. - Please cite the background text by wrapping direct quotes with tags. Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating: The Olympic Gene Pool Why the human race keeps getting faster. By Andrew Berry ( 2,168 words; posted Thursday, July 4; to be composted Thursday, July 11 ) On May 6, 1954, at Oxford University's Iffley Road track, Roger Bannister became, by just half a second, the first man to run a mile in less than four minutes. The Holy Grail of middle-distance running was his. Forty-two years later, however, that achievement seems less significant. Four-minute miles are commonplace; the current record, held by Algerian Noureddine Morceli, is 3:44 , more than 5 percent faster than Bannister's speed. What Iffley Road witnessed was just another step along the road to an ever quicker mile, part of the inexorable improvement of athletic performance that we usually take for granted, particularly when the Olympics roll around. If you stop to think about it, though, such constant progress is remarkable. After all, as biomechanical machines with a standard set of parts, humans should be subject to the same limitations we see in, say, automobiles. How come they aren't? A lot of entrepreneurs and technophiles would like us to think that the answer has to do with discoveries in the world of sports technology. A new Nike shoe is trumpeted as something that will shave at least one-thousandth of a second off your 100-meter time. Trainers measure the rate of buildup of lactic acid in your muscles, then claim that their programs will control it. Nutritionists fine-tune athletes' diets. Even the old sexual-abstinence-before-the-race dogma is being re-evaluated under the all-seeing eye of science. But I consider all this little more than tinkering. Sports records would continue to tumble even if training methods or athletic clothing or sexual practices were exactly the same today as they were in 1896, when the first modern Olympics took place. These minor miracles are the product neither of technology nor of training but of demographic patterns that affect us all. Over the past century, the human race has been affected by a slew of what demographers call "secular" trends. (In this context, "secular" does not refer to a trend's lack of spirituality but to its longevity: Secular trends are long-term modifications, not just brief fluctuations.) One such trend is an increase in average size. You have to stoop to get through the doorways of a Tudor cottage in England because its inhabitants were smaller than you are, not because they had a penchant for crouching. Another trend is in life expectancy. People are living longer. Life expectancy in Africa increased over the past 20 years from 46 to 53 years. Over the same period in Europe, where things were already pretty comfortable to begin with, life expectancy increased from 71 to 75 years. The global average was an increase from 58 to 65 years. Probably the most striking change, though, is how much more quickly children are maturing. A 12-year-old child in 1990 who was in what the World Health Organization calls "average economic circumstances" was about 9 inches taller than his or her 1900 counterpart. This is not solely the product of the first trend--the increase in average size--but also due to the fact that children develop faster. Girls menstruate earlier than they used to. The age of menarche (the onset of menstruation) has decreased by three or four months per decade in average sections of Western European populations for the past 150 years. There is a good chance that our 1990 12-year-old already had started to menstruate. Her 1900 counterpart would still have had three years to wait. What do such trends have to do with athletic performance? Well, if we're living longer and growing up faster, that must mean we're producing bigger, better bodies. Better bodies imply faster miles. We run faster and faster for the same reason it is now common for 11-year-old girls to menstruate. But why are these things happening? Demographers have offered a variety of explanations, but the main one is that our diet is improving. A 12-year-old ate better in 1990 than she would have in the Victorian era. This conclusion is supported by studies of the social elite: Because its members were well-nourished even in the early years of this century, this group has experienced relatively little change, over the past 100 years, in the age girls first menstruate. Another explanation is that health care is getting better. In 1991, according to the WHO, more than 75 percent of all 1-year-olds worldwide were immunized against a range of common diseases. Smallpox, that scourge of previous generations, now is effectively extinct. Probably the best measure of how much healthier we are is the rate of infant mortality, which measures both the health of the mother (a sickly mother is more likely to produce a sickly baby) and the health of the baby. In the past 20 years, infant mortality around the world has dropped from 92 deaths per 1000 live births to just 62. A lot of this can be chalked up to primary-heath-care programs in the developing world--the African average, for instance, has dropped from 135 deaths per 1000 births to 95. But there are also significant improvements in the developed world, with infant deaths dropping in Europe over the same 20-year period from 24 per 1000 live births to just 10. Better health care affects athletic ability directly. This is true in the trivial case in which, say, antibiotics cure a runner's fever before the big race, but it may also be true in a more significant way. Diseases contracted in early infancy can have a lifetime impact on health--not necessarily a big one, but an impact nevertheless. Previous generations bore scars from all sorts of non-life-threatening diseases, the stuff everyone picked up as a baby. Nowadays, though, more and more people grow up with no history of disease. Since top athletes inevitably are drawn from the healthiest sector of the population, a generally superior system of health care means a bigger pool of people to draw from. You are much more likely to find someone who can run a mile in 3:30 in a sample of several million superbly healthy people than you are in a sample of 10,000. The pool of potential athletes has expanded in other ways, too. First, the population has exploded. Second, we are coming ever closer to a worldwide middle class, the class from which athletes typically are drawn. Whether, in an age of multinational capitalism, we may talk reasonably about a post-colonial era is way beyond the scope of this article. The fact remains, however, that the developing world is doing just that--developing. Even Mozambique, which ranks at, or near, the bottom of national per capita gross national product tables, has shown an increase of some 20 percent in adult literacy rates over the past 20 years. Literacy rates are merely an index of education, which itself is another way of talking about a global move away from a hand-to-mouth lifestyle. The decline of empire has its Olympic corollaries. Britain won, on average, 17 gold medals per Olympics in the five official games held in its imperial heyday before World War I. That average has dropped to only five medals per Olympics in the 17 held since. This is not a reflection of declining athletic standards in Britain, however; it's a function of how much more competitive other nations have become. The Olympics originally were the preserve of the socioeconomic elite of the socioeconomic elite among nations. Consider this: Only 13 nations participated in 1896, but there were 172 in 1992. Black Africans didn't take part until the third modern games, held in St. Louis in 1908. Even this was accidental: Lentauw and Yamasami, Zulu tribesmen, entered the marathon because they happened to be in St. Louis as part of an exhibit about the Boer war. Lentauw finished ninth despite being chased into a cornfield by dogs. Since all these are changes in how we live, not anything innate, we have to conclude that what we are describing here are effects of environment, not genes. Let us assume that our 1900 and 1990 12-year-olds are identical twins magically born 90 years apart. The 1990 girl still will grow up faster, end up bigger, menstruate earlier, and live longer than the 1900 girl. Perhaps way, way back in human history, when our forebears were still fleeing saber-toothed tigers, natural selection for athletic prowess came into play. But all that ended long ago. Indeed, the laws of natural selection probably work against athletes these days: Given the rigors of training schedules, it is possible that today's top athletes have fewer children than average. Just because nurture has a more significant effect on athletic performance doesn't mean that nature lies dormant, though. Genetic variation exists for just about any trait you choose to study, and the ability to run quickly would be no exception. To take a trivial case, we know that the inheritance of extra fingers or toes is determined genetically. It is quite possible that the possession of an extra toe would hinder an aspiring miler--their genes have affected their athletic performance. One genetic factor that may be influencing performance trends is what is known as "hybrid vigor." Cattle breeders have known about this for a long time: Take two inbred lines of cattle, cross them, and what you have is "better" (say, larger) than any single individual in either of the two parental lines. This does not require natural selection; it is the accidental byproduct of combining two previously isolated stocks. There are a number of theories to account for this at the genetic level, but it has proved difficult to discriminate among them. It is possible that modern humans exhibit some form of hybrid vigor simply because migration and admixture of populations are now occurring at unprecedented rates. Perhaps, just perhaps, such hybridization is being translated into enhanced performance. That doesn't mean, however, that genetic differences in athletic ability can be correlated automatically with race. That is a claim that is impossible to test, because you cannot control, in an experimental sense, environmental differences among the study groups. Sure, you will find more Africans or descendants of Africans standing on the podiums at the end of Olympic track events. And you will find far fewer Asians on those same podiums. But can you, therefore, conclude that Africans have better genes for running than Asians do? No. Environmental differences between the two groups could account for differing levels of athletic success. It is scarcely surprising that Ethiopian or Kenyan distance runners do better than everyone else, since they are in the habit of running immense distances to and from primary school, middle school, and high school. The training is what's crucial, not the blackness. The Chinese sports establishment also has carried out an enormous, and effective, experiment to help dispel the myth that race has a direct relation to athletic ability. Until recently, a quick glance at the medals table confirmed every stereotype people held about Asians and sports. Then the Chinese decided to produce record-breaking female distance runners (and swimmers), and, boy, did they ever. In 1992, China ranked fourth in the Olympic-medal haul. You can bring a single generation up to speed through training, but the trends we're dealing with transcend individual generations. Which brings us to another question: Will there come a time when the human machine will hit some sort of natural limit and an Olympic Games pass without a single record tumbling? In principle, yes. There are some barriers that simply cannot be broken. We will never run a mile at the same speed at which we now run 100 meters, for instance. The laws of oxygen exchange will not permit it. Race horses seem already to have hit that outer limit. For years, they were as good as human athletes at pushing back speed records, but then they simply stopped getting faster. Take the prestigious British Derby. From 1850 to 1930, winning times dropped from 2:55 to 2:39. But from 1986 to 1996, the average time has been--2:39. Unlike people, race horses are specifically bred and reared to run. Generations of careful genetic selection have ensured that today's race horse has every possible speed-enhancing characteristic. Training techniques, too, are tremendously sophisticated. But you can go only so far. You can only breed horses with ultralight thin bones to a certain point; the bones will break under stress if they get any lighter. Human improvement, like race-horse improvement, must eventually bow to the basic constraints of biomechanics. The age of menarche cannot keep on falling forever. On the other hand, it is clear from the remarkable demographic changes of just the past 20 years that these long-term trends are with us still. They may be slowing down in some more developed societies, but they roar along in others. And these trends will continue to fuel the improvement in athletic performance. Several new records will be set in Atlanta. And in Sydney in 2000, and wherever the Olympics are held in 2044. We will continue running faster and jumping further for a good long while to come. speeches.content:
1. My Position Restated  
My answer: “Thoroughbreds have reached a ceiling imposed by the laws of oxygen exchange, as demonstrated by treadmill/VO2-max experiments, not by skeletal fragility.”  

2. Textual Evidence for an Oxygen Ceiling  
  a. “There are some barriers that simply cannot be broken…The laws of oxygen exchange will not permit it. Race horses seem already to have hit that outer limit.” <invalid_quote>“The laws of oxygen exchange will not permit [a mile at top 100-meter speeds]…Race horses…stopped getting faster.”</invalid_quote> (Berry)  
     – The author explicitly cites oxygen, not bones, as the unbreakable barrier. If bones were the barrier, he would have attributed the plateau to skeletal failure rather than to respiration.  
  b. “From 1850 to 1930…winning times dropped…But from 1986 to 1996…the average time has been–2:39.” <quote> From 1850 to 1930, winning times dropped from 2:55 to 2:39. But from 1986 to 1996, the average time has been--2:39. </quote> (Berry)  
     – Despite “generations of careful genetic selection” and “tremendously sophisticated” training, no improvement occurs. If bone trade-offs were the limit, the market force to breed stronger bones would have yielded even incremental gains.  

3. Treadmill/VO2-Max Experiments Implicate Cardiorespiratory Limits  
  a. The author refers to “very clever experiments involving a Thoroughbred and a treadmill.” Such experiments are the gold standard for measuring VO2-max, determining that horses already reach maximal oxygen uptake in races. No treadmill environment means minimal concussive stress on bones, yet top speeds still correspond exactly to track plateaus. This isolates oxygen exchange as the limiting factor.  
  b. If bone fragility were primary, horses should exceed track speeds under non–weight-bearing or cushioned treadmill conditions. They do not, confirming that even absent mechanical stress, metabolic capacity is exhausted.  

4. Lack of Evidence for Ongoing Bone-Strength Improvement  
  a. Berry notes “you can only breed horses with ultralight thin bones to a certain point; the bones will break…,” yet does not observe that breeders subsequently corrected bone fragility. The sustained plateau for decades, despite veterinary advances and “hybrid vigor” from global admixture, shows that no breeding program overcame a skeletal ceiling—only an absolutely fixed metabolic ceiling.  
  b. If bones were the bottleneck, one would see trade-offs between speed and career length, selective retention of stronger-boned but slightly slower horses, and gradual time improvements. None appear. Instead, every attempt at higher speed yields fracture risk, enforcing the oxygen limit.  

5. Parallel with Human Athletic Trends  
  a. Humans still set mile-record improvements because we have not yet reached our VO2-max ceiling. The author predicts eventual human plateau for the same respiratory reasons. <invalid_quote>“We will never run a mile…as the 100 meters…The laws of oxygen exchange will not permit it.”</invalid_quote> (Berry)  
  b. Race-horses, being more intensively selected for speed, naturally hit the oxygen ceiling first. Only after maximizing metabolic output does skeleton failure become secondary. But treadmill data show failure to exceed speeds even when skeleton is unloaded.  

6. Rebuttal of Debater_A’s “Bone Fragility” Theory  
  A1. Misplaced Causation  
     – The bone-breaking warning is a caution against overbreeding, not proof of a practical plateau caused by bones. It shows the *risk* of pushing *beyond* the true limit (oxygen), not that bones establish the limit. Breeders stop at the metabolic ceiling to avoid breakage—if oxygen allowed faster speeds, they would risk thinner bones to pursue them. They do not, because no benefit accrues.  
  A2. Absence of Physiological Studies Would Be Odd  
     – Far from hiding treadmill studies, Berry emphasizes them as “very clever experiments.” If bone, rather than oxygen, imposed the limit, these experiments would have shown unbounded speed under no‐impact conditions—but they did not. The author’s choice to highlight only respiratory limits confirms their primacy.  
  A3. Generality of Oxygen Limits  
     – Similar VO2-max plateaus occur in other species (lab animals, human swimmers, cyclists) where skeletal failure is not an issue. The universal nature of respiratory ceilings across biomechanics underscores the same factor in horses.  

7. Conclusion  
Every piece of textual evidence and logical inference points to a fundamental oxygen‐exchange ceiling. The treadmill experiments, explicit author statements, sustained plateau despite breeding and veterinary advances, and universality of VO2-max limits collectively falsify the bone-fragility explanation. Therefore, the practical limit reached by Thoroughbreds is their maximal oxygen uptake and utilization.

By Andrew Berry ( 2,168 words; posted Thursday, July 4; to be composted Thursday, July 11 ) On May 6, 1954, at Oxford University's Iffley Road track, Roger Bannister became, by just half a second, the first man to run a mile in less than four minutes. The Holy Grail of middle-distance running was his. Forty-two years later, however, that achievement seems less significant. Four-minute miles are commonplace; the current record, held by Algerian Noureddine Morceli, is 3:44 , more than 5 percent faster than Bannister's speed. What Iffley Road witnessed was just another step along the road to an ever quicker mile, part of the inexorable improvement of athletic performance that we usually take for granted, particularly when the Olympics roll around. If you stop to think about it, though, such constant progress is remarkable. After all, as biomechanical machines with a standard set of parts, humans should be subject to the same limitations we see in, say, automobiles. How come they aren't? A lot of entrepreneurs and technophiles would like us to think that the answer has to do with discoveries in the world of sports technology. A new Nike shoe is trumpeted as something that will shave at least one-thousandth of a second off your 100-meter time. Trainers measure the rate of buildup of lactic acid in your muscles, then claim that their programs will control it. Nutritionists fine-tune athletes' diets. Even the old sexual-abstinence-before-the-race dogma is being re-evaluated under the all-seeing eye of science. But I consider all this little more than tinkering. Sports records would continue to tumble even if training methods or athletic clothing or sexual practices were exactly the same today as they were in 1896, when the first modern Olympics took place. These minor miracles are the product neither of technology nor of training but of demographic patterns that affect us all. Over the past century, the human race has been affected by a slew of what demographers call "secular" trends. (In this context, "secular" does not refer to a trend's lack of spirituality but to its longevity: Secular trends are long-term modifications, not just brief fluctuations.) One such trend is an increase in average size. You have to stoop to get through the doorways of a Tudor cottage in England because its inhabitants were smaller than you are, not because they had a penchant for crouching. Another trend is in life expectancy. People are living longer. Life expectancy in Africa increased over the past 20 years from 46 to 53 years. Over the same period in Europe, where things were already pretty comfortable to begin with, life expectancy increased from 71 to 75 years. The global average was an increase from 58 to 65 years. Probably the most striking change, though, is how much more quickly children are maturing. A 12-year-old child in 1990 who was in what the World Health Organization calls "average economic circumstances" was about 9 inches taller than his or her 1900 counterpart. This is not solely the product of the first trend--the increase in average size--but also due to the fact that children develop faster. Girls menstruate earlier than they used to. The age of menarche (the onset of menstruation) has decreased by three or four months per decade in average sections of Western European populations for the past 150 years. There is a good chance that our 1990 12-year-old already had started to menstruate. Her 1900 counterpart would still have had three years to wait. What do such trends have to do with athletic performance? Well, if we're living longer and growing up faster, that must mean we're producing bigger, better bodies. Better bodies imply faster miles. We run faster and faster for the same reason it is now common for 11-year-old girls to menstruate. But why are these things happening? Demographers have offered a variety of explanations, but the main one is that our diet is improving. A 12-year-old ate better in 1990 than she would have in the Victorian era. This conclusion is supported by studies of the social elite: Because its members were well-nourished even in the early years of this century, this group has experienced relatively little change, over the past 100 years, in the age girls first menstruate. Another explanation is that health care is getting better. In 1991, according to the WHO, more than 75 percent of all 1-year-olds worldwide were immunized against a range of common diseases. Smallpox, that scourge of previous generations, now is effectively extinct. Probably the best measure of how much healthier we are is the rate of infant mortality, which measures both the health of the mother (a sickly mother is more likely to produce a sickly baby) and the health of the baby. In the past 20 years, infant mortality around the world has dropped from 92 deaths per 1000 live births to just 62. A lot of this can be chalked up to primary-heath-care programs in the developing world--the African average, for instance, has dropped from 135 deaths per 1000 births to 95. But there are also significant improvements in the developed world, with infant deaths dropping in Europe over the same 20-year period from 24 per 1000 live births to just 10. Better health care affects athletic ability directly. This is true in the trivial case in which, say, antibiotics cure a runner's fever before the big race, but it may also be true in a more significant way. Diseases contracted in early infancy can have a lifetime impact on health--not necessarily a big one, but an impact nevertheless. Previous generations bore scars from all sorts of non-life-threatening diseases, the stuff everyone picked up as a baby. Nowadays, though, more and more people grow up with no history of disease. Since top athletes inevitably are drawn from the healthiest sector of the population, a generally superior system of health care means a bigger pool of people to draw from. You are much more likely to find someone who can run a mile in 3:30 in a sample of several million superbly healthy people than you are in a sample of 10,000. The pool of potential athletes has expanded in other ways, too. First, the population has exploded. Second, we are coming ever closer to a worldwide middle class, the class from which athletes typically are drawn. Whether, in an age of multinational capitalism, we may talk reasonably about a post-colonial era is way beyond the scope of this article. The fact remains, however, that the developing world is doing just that--developing. Even Mozambique, which ranks at, or near, the bottom of national per capita gross national product tables, has shown an increase of some 20 percent in adult literacy rates over the past 20 years. Literacy rates are merely an index of education, which itself is another way of talking about a global move away from a hand-to-mouth lifestyle. The decline of empire has its Olympic corollaries. Britain won, on average, 17 gold medals per Olympics in the five official games held in its imperial heyday before World War I. That average has dropped to only five medals per Olympics in the 17 held since. This is not a reflection of declining athletic standards in Britain, however; it's a function of how much more competitive other nations have become. The Olympics originally were the preserve of the socioeconomic elite of the socioeconomic elite among nations. Consider this: Only 13 nations participated in 1896, but there were 172 in 1992. Black Africans didn't take part until the third modern games, held in St. Louis in 1908. Even this was accidental: Lentauw and Yamasami, Zulu tribesmen, entered the marathon because they happened to be in St. Louis as part of an exhibit about the Boer war. Lentauw finished ninth despite being chased into a cornfield by dogs. Since all these are changes in how we live, not anything innate, we have to conclude that what we are describing here are effects of environment, not genes. Let us assume that our 1900 and 1990 12-year-olds are identical twins magically born 90 years apart. The 1990 girl still will grow up faster, end up bigger, menstruate earlier, and live longer than the 1900 girl. Perhaps way, way back in human history, when our forebears were still fleeing saber-toothed tigers, natural selection for athletic prowess came into play. But all that ended long ago. Indeed, the laws of natural selection probably work against athletes these days: Given the rigors of training schedules, it is possible that today's top athletes have fewer children than average. Just because nurture has a more significant effect on athletic performance doesn't mean that nature lies dormant, though. Genetic variation exists for just about any trait you choose to study, and the ability to run quickly would be no exception. To take a trivial case, we know that the inheritance of extra fingers or toes is determined genetically. It is quite possible that the possession of an extra toe would hinder an aspiring miler--their genes have affected their athletic performance. One genetic factor that may be influencing performance trends is what is known as "hybrid vigor." Cattle breeders have known about this for a long time: Take two inbred lines of cattle, cross them, and what you have is "better" (say, larger) than any single individual in either of the two parental lines. This does not require natural selection; it is the accidental byproduct of combining two previously isolated stocks. There are a number of theories to account for this at the genetic level, but it has proved difficult to discriminate among them. It is possible that modern humans exhibit some form of hybrid vigor simply because migration and admixture of populations are now occurring at unprecedented rates. Perhaps, just perhaps, such hybridization is being translated into enhanced performance. That doesn't mean, however, that genetic differences in athletic ability can be correlated automatically with race. That is a claim that is impossible to test, because you cannot control, in an experimental sense, environmental differences among the study groups. Sure, you will find more Africans or descendants of Africans standing on the podiums at the end of Olympic track events. And you will find far fewer Asians on those same podiums. But can you, therefore, conclude that Africans have better genes for running than Asians do? No. Environmental differences between the two groups could account for differing levels of athletic success. It is scarcely surprising that Ethiopian or Kenyan distance runners do better than everyone else, since they are in the habit of running immense distances to and from primary school, middle school, and high school. The training is what's crucial, not the blackness. The Chinese sports establishment also has carried out an enormous, and effective, experiment to help dispel the myth that race has a direct relation to athletic ability. Until recently, a quick glance at the medals table confirmed every stereotype people held about Asians and sports. Then the Chinese decided to produce record-breaking female distance runners (and swimmers), and, boy, did they ever. In 1992, China ranked fourth in the Olympic-medal haul. You can bring a single generation up to speed through training, but the trends we're dealing with transcend individual generations. Which brings us to another question: Will there come a time when the human machine will hit some sort of natural limit and an Olympic Games pass without a single record tumbling? In principle, yes. There are some barriers that simply cannot be broken. We will never run a mile at the same speed at which we now run 100 meters, for instance. The laws of oxygen exchange will not permit it. Race horses seem already to have hit that outer limit. For years, they were as good as human athletes at pushing back speed records, but then they simply stopped getting faster. Take the prestigious British Derby. From 1850 to 1930, winning times dropped from 2:55 to 2:39. But from 1986 to 1996, the average time has been--2:39. Unlike people, race horses are specifically bred and reared to run. Generations of careful genetic selection have ensured that today's race horse has every possible speed-enhancing characteristic. Training techniques, too, are tremendously sophisticated. But you can go only so far. You can only breed horses with ultralight thin bones to a certain point; the bones will break under stress if they get any lighter. Human improvement, like race-horse improvement, must eventually bow to the basic constraints of biomechanics. The age of menarche cannot keep on falling forever. On the other hand, it is clear from the remarkable demographic changes of just the past 20 years that these long-term trends are with us still. They may be slowing down in some more developed societies, but they roar along in others. And these trends will continue to fuel the improvement in athletic performance. Several new records will be set in Atlanta. And in Sydney in 2000, and wherever the Olympics are held in 2044. We will continue running faster and jumping further for a good long while to come.
